Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The Consequences of Food Assessment and Cache Placement on Social Competition and Cache Pilfering in a Scatter-hoarding Tree Squirrel
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many animals hoard their food, hiding food items in various locations in order to retrieve them at a later date, for example, when resources are scarce. Scatter-hoarding animals store each food item in a different location and often engage in protective behaviors that may prevent their food stores (caches) from being stolen. These behaviors include handling food items extensively before burying them, travelling away from competitors to bury food, and carefully covering caches. Scatter-hoarding fox squirrels (Sciurus niger) perform unique behaviors (head flicks, paw manipulations) that allow them to determine the weight and value of individual food items and protect their caches accordingly. By using Global Positioning System (GPS) and tracking technology, behavioral observations, and DNA testing, the researchers will explore how these food protection behaviors contribute to successful cache retrieval or prevent theft of caches by other squirrels. This study also will explore whether individuals are more or less likely to steal from their relatives. The proposed research will fill a gap in the animal behavior literature by advancing our understanding of how animals recover food they have buried, and illuminating whether scatter-hoarding animals provide for their offspring or close relatives by allowing theft of their caches.

Studies of scatter-hoarding animals have yet to address key questions: do cache protection strategies deter theft by pilferers and help scatter-hoarding animals recover their caches? Fox squirrels (Sciurus niger) perform unique assessment behaviors (head flicks, paw manipulations) that allow them to adjust investments in caches. The proposed studies will determine how a squirrel's assessment of food is related to its investment in a cache, and whether these behaviors reduce pilferage. This study will use GPS data and radio-telemetry/passive transponders to measure caching and pilfering behavior. They will also amplify and sequence established microsatellite loci to estimate genetic relatedness and incorporate relatedness into models of cache retrieval and pilferage. Food-storing animals engage in cache protection behaviors because theft is common. Previous studies have failed to examine the complex relationship between food assessment, cache protection, social context and the long-term fate of caches. Moreover, most studies utilize artificial caches made by humans or laboratory animals. This field study will use an innovative, interdisciplinary approach to examine the pilferage of caches made by free-ranging squirrels. This study also will examine the relationship between kin selection and pilferage tolerance, support for which would have major implications for our understanding of scatter-hoarding and social behavior. All data and analyses will be made available via published manuscripts, conference presentations, reports to the NSF and otherwise as suggested by NSF guidelines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This dissertation research explored the relationship between food-storing behaviors of the fox squirrel (Sciurus niger) and how these behaviors are affected by competition and relatedness between squirrels. Fox squirrels are scatter hoarders, storing each food item in a different location. Squirrels also perform unique assessment behaviors (head flicks, paw manipulations) that may allow them to determine how valuable a nut is, and consequently, how much effort they should invest in protecting each food store (cache). Theft between individuals is common, and so animals must make some efforts to cache food items carefully to reduce the risk of loss from competitors.

We recorded free-ranging fox squirrels as they cached hazelnuts which had microchips implanted in them. We analyzed each video to determine how much time and effort squirrels put into assessing and burying each nut, and used GPS to mark where they buried each nut. We determined whether each cache was buried in an open location (such as a grassy lawn), or a concealed location (such as behind a shrub). The microchips allowed us to track where nuts were cached and how long they remained in their original locations.

We collected hair samples from the squirrels in the study in order to do DNA analyses that allowed us to find out the likelihood that individuals in the study were related to one another. We could then compare the relatedness of individuals with the proximity of their caches to those of other squirrels. Because squirrels steal from one another, burying nuts closer to those of relatives would increase the possibility that theft and the tolerance of theft among food-storing animals is a form of kin selection. Theft of caches, if it benefits relatives, could still increase an individual’s reproductive fitness.

Finally, we used agent-based computer models to create environments where squirrels could store food, steal food from competitors, or retrieve previously stored items. Their ability to retrieve previously cached food was based on how long their memory was. The top performing individuals could pass on their memory “genes,” which allowed us to explore how competition from individuals might impact memory length over hundreds of generations of evolution.

Our field study suggested that caches that were buried in more concealed areas stayed in place for a longer period of time than caches made in more open areas. On average, a cache remained in its original location for four days, but about six percent of buried nuts were forgotten and never retrieved by squirrels. Squirrels tended to bury nuts closer to the caches of related squirrels than to those of non-related squirrels. Overall, they buried nuts closest to their own previously made caches.

Our evolutionary simulation suggests that social interactions and competition may reduce some cognitive abilities. Specifically, the presence of pilferers in the environment leads to a shorter memory in populations who rely on memory to retrieve caches. This may be because a long memory may not benefit an animal who returns to previously made caches if those caches have already been robbed. The most successful strategy appears to be to retrieve recently made caches, and to do so often; squirrels who were more likely to cache than pilfer also had longer memories.
